repnme.cdata!: Ethiopia - Second Road Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Ethiopia Second Road Sector
            Development Project had a moderate satisfactory outcome
            based on the administering of costs and Project preparation.
            Ratings for the Project were as follows: Risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory.  The Ethiopian Roads Authority
            (ERA) was ultimately responsible for the supervision of the
            road project. In general, all projects in the Adaptable
            Program Lending II (APL2) were characterized by cost
            overruns, costly design changes, schedule delays and issues
            with quality of work and engagement with consultants and
            contractors. The experience demonstrates that there is still
            scope for ERA to improve in areas of project and design
            management, construction risk management, value engineering
            and asset management. Lessons learned from the
            implementation of the APL2 include: (A) The ERA should
            set-up a Technical Panel to focus on risk management and
            value engineering of projects during preparation. (B)
            Strategically driven and holistic capacity building, and
            competitive remuneration is needed to attract and retain the
            best staff. (C) Focus on improving cost effectiveness by
            better analysis of the reasons for high costs, understanding
            the reasons for cost variation and working collaboratively
            with contractors to reduce costs across the entire project
            portfolio. Overall, the project was instrumental in
            successfully demonstrating the impacts achieved by combining
            road provision with non-transport projects to improve access
            and mobility.

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Additional Financing for the
            Second Road Sector Development Support Program Adaptable
            Program Lending (APL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Additional
            Financing for the Second Road Sector Development Support
            Program Adaptable Program Lending (APL) Project for Ethiopia
            are to: a) assist the recipient in increasing its road
            transport infrastructure and improving the reliability
            thereof, strengthening the capacity for road construction,
            management and maintenance; and b) creating conditions
            conducive to private sector participation in the road
            transport sector. The additional financing will primarily be
            used to complete the second stage of the  APL by covering
            cost overrun related to surface type design change from
            double bituminous surface treatment (DBST) to asphalt
            concrete (AC) surface responding to the growing traffic and
            expansion of town and urban sections reflecting recent
            economic growth and urbanization on some of the roads,
            increased quantities of work items, as well as construction
            materials price escalation in the recent years.

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Second Roads Sector Development
            Support Project (Adaptable Program Lending) - additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Sector Development Phase 2
            Project - APL2, within its support to the overall Road
            Sector Development Program Phase II, will increase the road
            transport infrastructure and improve its reliability,
            strengthen the capacity for road construction, management
            and maintenance, and ensure sustainability and create
            conditions conducive to private sector participation in the
            road transport sector. These objectives are achievable
            through: (a) construction, rehabilitation, upgrading and
            preserving the priority federal and regional road network;
            (b) strengthened Ethiopian Roads Authority reform program;
            (c) developing the capacity in program implementation; and
            (d) improving rural travel and transport services.
